resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.MSG.Free Exploration: Math Time
resources.title: Free Exploration: Math Time
resources.short_description: Focus: Explore math manipulatives.

content.text:
Invite children to hold hands and stand in a circle as you gather them for math small group. Sing Friends by My Side with Richele. Count the number of children in the group and insert the number in the lyrics. For example: I’ve got 5 friends by my side.

Friends by My Side

(Tune: He’s Got the Whole World in His Hands)

I’ve got ____ friends by my side.

I’ve got ____ friends by my side.

I’ve got ____ friends by my side.

I’ve got ____ friends by my side.
content.title: Music and Movement

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • observe

PHOTO CARDS

  • math small group #5

OTHER MATERIALS

  • prepared bags of math manipulatives
Math activities are intended to be taught in a small group.

columns.text: Display the observe Vocabulary Card and the math small group Photo Card. Gather the prepared bags of math manipulatives.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Introduce the math small group Photo Card. Invite children to repeat the words with you. Ask them to describe what they think the children in the photo are doing. If needed, provide suggestions, such as exploring, making designs with shapes, or counting.

Ask, How is this picture the same as the group of friends at this table? Explain to children they will gather in a small group each day to learn math.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Give each child a bag of math manipulatives. Invite them to observe the items. Refer to the observe Vocabulary Card and explain it means to touch, listen, or look at something closely. Encourage children to describe the manipulatives using their senses.
columns.title: Develop

framework_items.full_statement: Comparison and Differentiation
Child can recite the numerical order sequence correctly.
Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.MSG.Free Exploration: Attribute Buttons
resources.title: Free Exploration: Attribute Buttons
resources.short_description: Focus: Explore math manipulatives.

columns.text: Display the attributes and observe Vocabulary Cards. Place the attribute buttons on a tray.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Review the definition of observe. Say, Attributes describe how something looks, sounds, smells, tastes, or feels. Explain how you observe objects to find their attributes.

Point to the attribute buttons. Invite children to take a handful and explain how the buttons they might find on clothing are alike and different from the buttons in their hand.

Continue to use the words observe and attributes as they describe the buttons.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Ask, What colors do you see? How are the shapes alike and different? What does it sound like when a button falls against the table?

Encourage children to share a button with the group and describe its attributes.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • observe
  • attrbutes

OTHER MATERIALS

  • attribute buttons
  • tray

differential_instruction.text: SUPPORT children by framing questions with the specific attribute you are focusing on. For example: Which buttons are small? Large? Red? Round?

content.text: observe, attributes

framework_items.full_statement: Child can recite the numerical order sequence correctly.
Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).
Comparison and Differentiation

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.MSG.Free Exploration: Frog Counters
resources.title: Free Exploration: Frog Counters
resources.short_description: Focus: Explore math manipulatives.

content.text: observe, attributes, compare

columns.text: Display the observe, attributes, and compare Vocabulary Cards. Gather two frog counters for each child.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Review the words observe and attributes.

Distribute one frog counter to each child. Invite children to observe the attributes. Ask, What animal does it look like? How do you know?

Define compare as setting two items side by side to figure out how they are alike and different.

Distribute another frog counter that is a different color and size to each child. Invite children to observe and compare the attributes.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Ask, What is the alike? What is different?

Encourage children to tell about the attributes they see. Invite them to look at their classmate’s frog counters and describe what is alike and different.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • observe
  • attrbutes
  • compare

OTHER MATERIALS

  • frog counters (assorted colors and sizes)

multilingual_learners.text: Provide visual cues to help children compare likenesses and differences. Display the alike Vocabulary Card when you ask children to compare by likeness and the different Vocabulary Card when you focus on differences.

framework_items.full_statement: Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).
Comparison and Differentiation
Child can recite the numerical order sequence correctly.

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.MSG.Free Exploration: Connecting Cubes
resources.title: Free Exploration: Connecting Cubes
resources.short_description: Focus: Explore math manipulatives.

content.text: take apart, put together

columns.text: Display the take apart and put together Vocabulary Cards and gather 10 connecting cubes for each child.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Refer to the take apart and put together Vocabulary Cards. Use connecting cubes to model these words as children observe your movements. Distribute the connecting cubes, and invite children to explore the attributes.

Ask, How are the cubes alike and different? What colors do you see?

Invite a volunteer to put together and take apart the cubes. Guide children who are tempted to use their teeth to use the muscles in their hands and fingers instead.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Ask, What does it feel like to connect the cubes?

Invite children to build something. Encourage them to describe the object’s attributes, such as color, shape, and size.
columns.title: Develop

inclusive_strategies.text: Modify the activity by providing 5, rather than 10, connecting cubes. Encourage children to describe one attribute, such as color or size. Model for children with developmental delays how to compare based on one attribute, such as color.

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • take apart
  • put together

OTHER MATERIALS

  • connecting cubes

framework_items.full_statement: Child can recite the numerical order sequence correctly.
Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).
Comparison and Differentiation

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.MSG.Free Exploration: Match the Manipulatives
resources.title: Free Exploration: Match the Manipulatives
resources.short_description: Focus: Explore math manipulatives.

content.text: match

columns.text: Gather the prepared bins of manipulatives, labels, and storage bags. Display the match Vocabulary Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Model labeling each bin of manipulatives. Explain to children the labels will help them find where each manipulative belongs.

Say, Another way to do math is by matching objects. Point to the match Vocabulary Card and define as something that has similar attributes.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Give each child a bag of manipulatives. Encourage them to place each manipulative in the matching bin.

Ask, How do you know you placed each manipulative in the correct bin? Invite children to select one of the bins to explore with a partner.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • match

OTHER MATERIALS

  • storage bags
  • Manipulative Storage Labels and bins

framework_items.full_statement: Child can recite the numerical order sequence correctly.
Comparison and Differentiation
Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.mind-move.Mountain Pose
resources.title: Mountain Pose
resources.short_description: Mindful Movement practice with Mountain Pose

content.text:
Learn the Pose

This week we are beginning our mindful movement practice with Mountain Pose. Standing strong, steady, and centered in Mountain Pose helps to improve posture, alignment, and balance.

Mountain Pose

Mountain Pose seems very simple but helps us stay rooted and connected. It is an important foundation of many other poses, too. We will build on Mountain Pose in Week 2.

Provide an open and safe space for children to learn and practice the pose.

  • Stand tall and press your legs firmly into the ground.
  • Let your spine be long. Your head reaches up towards the sky.
  • Press your palms together firmly. Stay rooted into the ground like a strong mountain.
  • Practice holding a strong Mountain Pose for up to 1 minute.
content.title: Mountain Pose

inclusive_strategies.text: To modify Mountain Pose, stand with feet together or apart. Another option is to stand firmly on the ground with hands on the waist.

columns.text:
What You’ll Need:

  • 5 Minutes
  • Indoor or Outdoor Space
  • No Mat Required
columns.title: Set Up for Success!

content.text:
• Start with calm in Mountain Pose, by pressing your palms firmly together. Stay rooted into the ground. Take a nice breath in, and let it all out. Repeat for 3 to 4 breaths.
  • Move to silly by inviting children to be playful. Say, 1, 2, 3. Get silly! Allow children to be silly for 30 to 60 seconds.
  • Return to calm in Mountain Pose. Have children press their hands together and take several breaths in and out.
  • Repeat the Silly to Calm mindfulness activity up to three times. End with calm.
content.title: Silly to Calm Mindfulness

content.text: This activity is meant to be done in a large group or whole class. You can also use it for transitions.

framework_items.full_statement: Child exhibits steady improvement in fine-motor tasks
Child can successfully execute a range of activities exercising large muscles such as jumping, running, climbing, and balancing.
Task Execution is observed informally or formally.

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #1: Day 1 - Marvelous Me
resources.title: Read Aloud #1: Day 1 - Marvelous Me
resources.short_description: Day 1 instruction for literacy, using the Marvelous Me book.

content.text:
HERE ARE MY EARS

Here are my ears.

Here is my nose.

Here are my fingers.

Here are my toes.

 

Here are my eyes

Both open wide.

Here is my mouth

With white teeth inside.

 

Here is my tongue

That helps me speak.

Here is my chin

And here are my cheeks.

 

Here are my hands

That help me play.

Here are my feet

For walking today.
content.title: Action Rhyme

columns.text: Display Marvelous Me and the marvelous and illustrator Vocabulary Cards.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Say marvelous and invite children to say the word with you again.

Define marvelous as wonderful and the very best quality. Explain they will hear and use this word many times this week.

Introduce the book, highlighting the author and illustrator. Explain the author writes the words and the illustrator creates the pictures.

Facilitate a picture walk of the book. Invite children to make comments, describe the pictures, and make connections.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Ask, What are the children doing? Have you done things like this before? After, perform the action rhyme Here Are My Ears.
columns.title: Develop

did_you_know.text: We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. This includes stories we as adults don’t enjoy or are tired of. We should read each time with voice and excitement. This sparks joy and interest for our children and brings them to love the act of reading.

content.text:
BOOK

  • Marvelous Me 

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous
  • illustrator

multilingual_learners.text: Point to the body part being featured for children who are at pre-production level of language development. Ask them to say the body part in their home language, then in English.

cultural_responsiveness.text:
Using American Sign Language with children can be helpful in bridging communication gaps. Teach children some basic signs: thank you, please, friend.

Friend: Curve both index fingers into a ‘C’ shape. With one hand’s index finger pointing up, hook the other hand’s index finger into it. Then switch hand positions and repeat, as if your fingers are hugging.

Please: Place your flat hand with your fingers together near your chest and make a circular motion, as if you were rubbing your chest in a circular motion. This sign indicates a polite request or asking for something politely.

Thank You: Start with your dominant hand flat, near your lips. Move it forward and slightly downward toward the person you’re thanking.

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Vocabulary Expansion
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #2: Super Bodies
resources.title: Read Aloud #2: Super Bodies
resources.short_description: Day 1 instruction for literacy, using the My Super Body book

columns.text: Display My Super Body and the super Vocabulary Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text: Say super and invite children to say the word with you. Define super as very great. Introduce the book, highlighting the word super in the title. Explain our book is about our super bodies and how great they are! Read the story.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Ask, What are some things the boy’s body can do? What can your body do that is super? Accept all answers from children as they are providing their own opinion and perception of their body.
columns.title: Develop

content.text: super

columns.text:
Invite children to sing I Am Special with Thomas Moore.  

Song: I AM SPECIAL

©Thomas Moore

I am special, I am special (echo)

Just because I’m me, Just because I’m me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may be tall, I may be tall (echo)

I may be short, I may be short (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may have long hair, I may have long hair (echo)

I may have short hair, I might have short hair (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may be a boy, I may be a boy (echo)

I may be a girl, I may be a girl (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I am a child, I am a child (echo)

And I love myself, And I love myself (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope you like me; I hope you like me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

Just because I’m me, Just because I’m me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)
columns.title: Music & Movement

content.text:
Invite children to sing I Am Special with Thomas Moore.

 

Song: I AM SPECIAL

©Thomas Moore

I am special, I am special (echo)

Just because I’m me, Just because I’m me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may be tall, I may be tall (echo)

I may be short, I may be short (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may have long hair, I may have long hair (echo)

I may have short hair, I might have short hair (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I may be a boy, I may be a boy (echo)

I may be a girl, I may be a girl (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I am a child, I am a child (echo)

And I love myself, And I love myself (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope you like me; I hope you like me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

Just because I’m me, Just because I’m me (echo)

I am special, I am special (echo)

I hope that you like me, I hope that you like me (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)

I’m special, I’m special (echo)
content.title: Music and Movement

inclusive_strategies.text:
Teach children the ASL sign for special and encourage them to use it when they hear the word in the I am Special song.

Special: Form both hands into an “S” shape by extending your pinkie and thumb while keeping your other fingers curled into your palms. Bring both “S” hands together, with the fingertips touching, then move them apart in a circular motion while keeping the fingertips in contact. This motion signifies something unique or cherished.

content.text:
BOOKS

  • My Super Body

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • super

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books
Purposeful Word Usage

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #1: Day 2 - Helpful Hands
resources.title: Read Aloud #1: Day 2 - Helpful Hands
resources.short_description: Day 2 instruction for literacy, using the Marvelous Me book.

content.text:
BOOK

  • Marvelous Me 

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous
  • helpful

PHOTO CARDS

  • hands #1

multilingual_learners.text: Point to the body part being featured for children who are at pre-production level of language development. Ask them to say the body part in their home language, then in English.

cultural_responsiveness.text:
Using American Sign Language with children can be helpful in bridging communication gaps. Teach children some basic signs: thank you, please, friend.

Friend: Curve both index fingers into a ‘C’ shape. With one hand’s index finger pointing up, hook the other hand’s index finger into it. Then switch hand positions and repeat, as if your fingers are hugging.

Please: Place your flat hand with your fingers together near your chest and make a circular motion, as if you were rubbing your chest in a circular motion. This sign indicates a polite request or asking for something politely.

Thank You: Start with your dominant hand flat, near your lips. Move it forward and slightly downward toward the person you’re thanking.

columns.text: Display Marvelous Me, the marvelous and helpful Vocabulary Cards, and the hands Photo Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Review the word marvelous. Invite children to say the word. Introduce the word helpful, defining it as useful.     

Point to the hands Photo Card and discuss how hands are marvelous and helpful.

Read the book, highlighting where hands were helpful (drawing a picture, pouring milk, playing a game).
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Invite children to describe what they do with their hands. Ask children to put their hands behind their back and imagine how they would brush their teeth. Ask, How will you brush your teeth without your hands? Remind children their hands are helpful.
columns.title: Develop

did_you_know.text: We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. This includes stories we as adults don’t enjoy or are tired of. We should read each time with voice and excitement. This sparks joy and interest for our children and brings them to love the act of reading.

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books
Vocabulary Expansion

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #1: Day 3 - Awesome Arms
resources.title: Read Aloud #1: Day 3 - Awesome Arms
resources.short_description: Day 3 instruction for literacy, using the Marvelous Me book

content.text:
BOOK

  • Marvelous Me 

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous
  • reach

PHOTO CARDS

  • hands #1

columns.text: Display Marvelous Me and the marvelous and reach Vocabulary Cards.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Review the word marvelous. Invite a child to give a definition. Remind children their hands are marvelous and awesome.

Introduce the word reach. Explain they reach when they stretch their arms. Demonstrate reaching for an object.

Read the book, highlighting where children used their arms for climbing, somersaulting, and dancing. Encourage children to mimic the motions by reaching their arms.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Invite children to discuss what they do with their arms. Prompt children to give their neighbor a high-five. Ask, How were your arms helpful when giving a high-five?

Invite children to stand and participate in the action rhyme Stretch.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
(action rhyme)

Stretch to the ceiling. 

Stretch to the floor. 

Stretch to the wall. 

Stretch to the door.
content.title: Stretch

did_you_know.text: We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. This includes stories we as adults don’t enjoy or are tired of. We should read each time with voice and excitement. This sparks joy and interest for our children and brings them to love the act of reading.

inclusive_strategies.text:
Action rhymes are challenging for children with motor issues if a child has limited use of body parts. Adapt the activity to include only those body parts that are applicable. For example, children in a wheelchair might only be able to use their hands and shoulders.

Children who are not able to stand can complete their stretches from a seated position.

multilingual_learners.text: Point to the body part being featured for children who are at pre-production level of language development. Ask them to say the body part in their home language, then in English.

cultural_responsiveness.text:
Using American Sign Language with children can be helpful in bridging communication gaps. Teach children some basic signs: thank you, please, friend.

Friend: Curve both index fingers into a ‘C’ shape. With one hand’s index finger pointing up, hook the other hand’s index finger into it. Then switch hand positions and repeat, as if your fingers are hugging.

Please: Place your flat hand with your fingers together near your chest and make a circular motion, as if you were rubbing your chest in a circular motion. This sign indicates a polite request or asking for something politely.

Thank You: Start with your dominant hand flat, near your lips. Move it forward and slightly downward toward the person you’re thanking.

framework_items.full_statement: Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books
Vocabulary Expansion
Listening Comprehension

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #1: Day 4 - Fabulous Feet
resources.title: Read Aloud #1: Day 4 - Fabulous Feet
resources.short_description: Day 4 instruction for literacy, using the Marvelous Me book.

content.text:
Invite children to sing and march to I Like Me with Ronno. Encourage children to pay attention to their feet as they march.

 

Song: I LIKE ME

Ronno

Lyrics by Judy Millar, Liz Jones-Twomey, Ron Hiller/RONNO, Pam Schiller © Song Support SOCAN

Verse 1:

I like my skin

It’s the house I’m living in

Well, it zips up tight

And it fits just right

So I like my skin.

And I like my nose

I kinda like the way it blows.

It honks good and loud

And that draws a crowd

So, I like my nose.

Chorus:

And I like me

I’m an OK me to be!

Though I’m not like you

That’s OK, too . . .

‘Cause I like me.

(Repeat chorus after each verse.)

Verse 2:

I like my lips

Hey, they’re great for catching drips.

And when I want a kiss

Well, I never miss

Yes, I like my lips.

And I like my knees

‘though they rattle when I sneeze.

They just bend one way

But that’s OK

‘Cause I like my knees.

(Repeat chorus after each verse.)

Verse 3:

Now, I like my feet

They get a good grip on the street.

You might say they smell

But I think they’re swell

‘Cause I like my feet.

And I like my hair

I’d like to grow it down to there.

But then all I’d do

Would just be shampoo!

Still, I like my hair.

(Repeat chorus after each verse.)

Verse 4:

Well, I like my brain

Like spaghetti in a drain.

Sometimes my thoughts

Get tied in knots

But I like my brain.

And I like my heart

It’s my very finest part.

It’s the part that shares

And the part that cares

Yes, I like my heart.

(Repeat chorus after each verse.)
content.title: Music and Movement

columns.text: Display Marvelous Me, the marvelous Vocabulary Card, and the feet Photo Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Talk about the word marvelous. Invite a few children to use the word when speaking about their classmates.

Introduce the words fabulous and wonderful. Explain these words mean the same as marvelous, the very best quality.

We use these words to describe things we love and enjoy.

Point to the feet Photo Card. Discuss the marvelous things you can do with your feet (kick a ball, dance, skip, hop, jump, climb, pedal a tricycle).

Read the book, highlighting where children used their feet.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Ask, How do your feet help you get from here to there? How can walking be faster than crawling? Point out feet help us do many things. Our feet are marvelous!
columns.title: Develop

did_you_know.text: We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. This includes stories we as adults don’t enjoy or are tired of. We should read each time with voice and excitement. This sparks joy and interest for our children and brings them to love the act of reading.

multilingual_learners.text: Point to the body part being featured for children who are at pre-production level of language development. Ask them to say the body part in their home language, then in English.

cultural_responsiveness.text:
Using American Sign Language with children can be helpful in bridging communication gaps. Teach children some basic signs: thank you, please, friend.

Friend: Curve both index fingers into a ‘C’ shape. With one hand’s index finger pointing up, hook the other hand’s index finger into it. Then switch hand positions and repeat, as if your fingers are hugging.

Please: Place your flat hand with your fingers together near your chest and make a circular motion, as if you were rubbing your chest in a circular motion. This sign indicates a polite request or asking for something politely.

Thank You: Start with your dominant hand flat, near your lips. Move it forward and slightly downward toward the person you’re thanking.

content.text:
BOOK

  • Marvelous Me 

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

PHOTO CARDS

  • feet #2

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Vocabulary Expansion
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #1: Day 5 - Wonderful Legs
resources.title: Read Aloud #1: Day 5 - Wonderful Legs
resources.short_description: Day 5 instruction for literacy, using the Marvelous Me book

multilingual_learners.text: Point to the body part being featured for children who are at pre-production level of language development. Ask them to say the body part in their home language, then in English.

cultural_responsiveness.text:
Using American Sign Language with children can be helpful in bridging communication gaps. Teach children some basic signs: thank you, please, friend.

Friend: Curve both index fingers into a ‘C’ shape. With one hand’s index finger pointing up, hook the other hand’s index finger into it. Then switch hand positions and repeat, as if your fingers are hugging.

Please: Place your flat hand with your fingers together near your chest and make a circular motion, as if you were rubbing your chest in a circular motion. This sign indicates a polite request or asking for something politely.

Thank You: Start with your dominant hand flat, near your lips. Move it forward and slightly downward toward the person you’re thanking.

did_you_know.text: We have an obligation to read aloud to our children. This includes stories we as adults don’t enjoy or are tired of. We should read each time with voice and excitement. This sparks joy and interest for our children and brings them to love the act of reading.

content.text:
BOOK

  • Marvelous Me 

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

columns.text: Display Marvelous Me and the marvelous Vocabulary Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Say, Our legs are marvelous! Invite children to use the word marvelous to describe their body. Say, Our legs help us to stand, kneel, and extend the reach of our feet.

Read the book, highlighting where children used their wonderful legs.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Invite children to discuss how they use their legs. Ask, What parts do you see on your leg? Where is your knee? How does it help your legs?

Invite volunteers to kneel, hop, jump, and march. Point out they are using both their legs and feet to do these movements. Encourage all children to do the same while being mindful of safety in the classroom.
columns.title: Develop

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books
Vocabulary Expansion

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #2: Marvelous Face
resources.title: Read Aloud #2: Marvelous Face
resources.short_description: Day 2 instruction for literacy, using the My Super Body book

content.text:
(Tune: "Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes")

Eyes, eyebrows, mouth and nose, Mouth and nose.

Eyes, eyebrows, mouth and nose, Mouth and nose.

Eyes and eyebrows mouth and nose.

Eyes, eyebrows mouth and nose, Mouth and nose. 

(Repeat)
content.title: Song Lyrics: Eyes, Eyebrows, Mouth and Nose

content.text: marvelous, expression

inclusive_strategies.text: For learners with partial blindness, full blindness, and low vision, ask children to describe their own faces based on touch.

multilingual_learners.text: Encourage learners in the pre- production stage to give a “thumbs up” or “thumbs down” to indicate their understanding throughout the story. Beforehand, practice the hand motions with them so they feel comfortable.

differential_instruction.text: SUPPORT children by asking simple yes/no questions to support learning. For example: Did you see your ears? Some children may get overwhelmed with open-ended questions. This is an easy way to scaffold for understanding.

columns.text: Display My Super Body, the marvelous and expression Vocabulary Cards, and the face Photo Card. Gather a mirror for each child.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Remind children marvelous means the very best quality.

Point to the face Photo Card and explain our faces are marvelous because they can show how we feel. Read the story.

Review pages 2-3. Ask, How do you think the boy is feeling? What makes you think so? Say, The smile on his face shows he is happy. This is called an expression. An expression is the look on our face that lets others know how we are feeling.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Distribute a small mirror to each child. Invite children to examine their own expressions of happiness. After, invite children to sing Eyes, Eyebrows, Mouth and Nose.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
BOOK

  • My Super Body

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous
  • expression

PHOTO CARDS

  • face #3

OTHER MATERIALS

  • small mirror for each child

framework_items.full_statement: Listening Comprehension
Purposeful Word Usage
Develop an appreciation for music and participate in music and movement activities that represent a variety of the cultures and the home language of the children in the classroom.
Ability to Comprehend Story Elements from books
Attempt to sing songs with words and later sing phrases of songs.

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read Aloud #2: Super Ears
resources.title: Read Aloud #2: Super Ears
resources.short_description: Day 3 instruction for literacy, using the My Super Body book

columns.text: Display My Super Body, the marvelous Vocabulary Card, and the ear Photo Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Point to the ear Photo Card. Explain the part of the ear you can see is the outer ear. Inside the ear is where our hearing takes place, which is called the inner ear.

Discuss the earlobe and encourage children to feel their own earlobe. Say, Our ears are marvelous.

Read the book, pausing on page 11 to invite children to answer the question.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text:
Ask, What did the boy hear with his ears? What are some things you have heard today?

Encourage children to close their eyes and listen to the sounds.

Ask, What do you hear now? Point out some sounds are nice to hear (soft music, kind words) and some sounds can be annoying (sirens, yelling).
columns.title: Develop

multilingual_learners.text: Encourage learners in the pre- production stage to give a “thumbs up” or “thumbs down” to indicate their understanding throughout the story. Beforehand, practice the hand motions with them so they feel comfortable.

differential_instruction.text: SUPPORT children by asking simple yes/no questions to support learning. For example: Did you see your ears? Some children may get overwhelmed with open-ended questions. This is an easy way to scaffold for understanding.

content.text: marvelous

BOOK

  • My Super Body

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

PHOTO CARDS

  • ear #4

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read-Aloud #2 - Day 4: Marvelous Nose
resources.title: Read-Aloud #2 - Day 4: Marvelous Nose
resources.short_description: Day 4 instruction for literacy, using the My Super Body book.

content.text:
BOOK

  • My Super Body

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

PHOTO CARDS

  • face #3

columns.text: Display My Super Body, the marvelous Vocabulary Card, and the face Photo Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Say, Our face is marvelous! Refer to the face Photo Card. Ask a volunteer to point to the nose. Explain the holes are called nostrils. Describe how smells and air travel inside the nose through the nostrils. Some things smell nice like apple pie, while other things smell bad, like a dirty diaper.

Read the book, pausing on page 13 to invite children to answer the question.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Ask, What did the boy smell? Play a smell game by naming different scents (perfume, onion, garbage, cookies baking, dirty socks). Have children sniff the air for a good smell and hold their nose for a bad smell. Accept all perspectives and responses.
columns.title: Develop

multilingual_learners.text: Encourage learners in the pre- production stage to give a “thumbs up” or “thumbs down” to indicate their understanding throughout the story. Beforehand, practice the hand motions with them so they feel comfortable.

differential_instruction.text: SUPPORT children by asking simple yes/no questions to support learning. For example: Did you see your ears? Some children may get overwhelmed with open-ended questions. This is an easy way to scaffold for understanding.

content.text: marvelous

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.RAs.Read-Aloud #2 - Day 5: Super Mouth
resources.title: Read-Aloud #2 - Day 5: Super Mouth
resources.short_description: Day 5 instruction for literacy, using the My Super Body book.

content.text: marvelous

columns.text: Display My Super Body, the marvelous Vocabulary Card, and the face Photo Card.
columns.title: Prepare

columns.text:
Refer to the face Photo Card. Ask a volunteer to point out the mouth, cheeks, and chin. Ask, What do you do with your mouth? 

Provide ideas such as eat breakfast, talk, smile, and give a kiss. Remind children that marvelous means the very best quality. Say, Our mouths are marvelous!

Read the book, pausing on page 15 to invite children to answer the question.
columns.title: Discover

columns.text: Ask, What was the boy waiting to taste with his mouth? After, invite children to echo the Warm-Up Chant. Children should repeat each line after you say it.
columns.title: Develop

content.text:
(children echo each line)

I love myself.

I feel so good.

This is my nose.

I smell with my nose.

I blow my nose.

I have holes in my nose.

I love my nose.  

There are my ears.

I wash my ears.

I hear with my ears.

I have holes in my ears.

These are my teeth.

I brush my teeth.

I floss my teeth.

I chew with my teeth.

I love my teeth.  

This is my chin,

my chinny-chin-chin.

I don’t know why I have it.

I love my chin!
content.title: Song Lyrics: Warm-Up Chant by Thomas Moore

content.text:
BOOK

  • My Super Body

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

PHOTO CARDS

  • face #3

inclusive_strategies.text: Children who are nonverbal may still make sounds and shapes with their mouths (such as an “O” shape, a smile, a frown, etc.).

multilingual_learners.text: Encourage learners in the pre- production stage to give a “thumbs up” or “thumbs down” to indicate their understanding throughout the story. Beforehand, practice the hand motions with them so they feel comfortable.

differential_instruction.text: SUPPORT children by asking simple yes/no questions to support learning. For example: Did you see your ears? Some children may get overwhelmed with open-ended questions. This is an easy way to scaffold for understanding.

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.steam.Block Play
resources.title: Block Play
resources.short_description: STEAM activity involving building with blocks

content.text:
Provide a large storage tub with blocks. Tell children they can build and design things when they use their imagination.

Introduce the blocks children can use to build. Invite each child to select a block to observe closely. Prompt children to describe the block. Ask, Which blocks are good for making walls, rooftops, or roads? Which blocks roll when you place them on the ground? What could you use those blocks for?

Invite children to build structures throughout the week using various blocks.
content.title: Activity

content.text:
• blocks
  • large storage tub

framework_items.full_statement: Compare, compose and explore shapes
Recognizes differences in shapes
Application of Measurement
'Child analyzes results and makes conclusions'
'Child formulates hypotheses or predictions'
Can describe shapes with basic language

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.steam.Construction Center
resources.title: Construction Center
resources.short_description: STEAM activity involving building with blocks

content.text: Invite children to explore and build with blocks. Remind them blocks are used for building or designing make-believe structures. Orient blocks in different ways (flat, horizontally, vertically) to provide ideas of how to use blocks for different purposes. Take a picture of children’s structures and display the photos during Closing Circle.
content.title: Building Structures

content.text:
• blocks
  • pretend-play materials (toy animals, cars, etc.)

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.mmt.Music, Movement, and Transitions (Theme 1, week 1)
resources.title: Music, Movement, and Transitions (Theme 1, week 1)
resources.short_description: Ideas to create smooth transitions from one activity to another and to offer children movement opportunities throughout the day

content.text:
Open, shut them, open, shut them.

Give a little clap, clap, clap.

Open, shut them, open, shut them.

Place them in your lap.

Creep them, Creep them,

Creep them, Creep them,

Right up to your chin.

Open wide your little mouth,

But do not let them in.

Open, shut them, open, shut them.

Give a little clap, clap, clap.

Open, shut them, open, shut them.

Place them in your lap.
content.title: Enjoy Anytime!

content.text: Create space in your room! Before beginning a music activity, have children spread their arms and turn around. Explain they should make this turn without touching anyone or anything.
content.title: Music and Movement

content.text:
During cleaning transitions, allow children to sing Can You Put the Toys Away? with Richele.

 

Song Lyrics: Can You Put the Toys Away

(Tune: “Do You Know the Muffin Man?”) 

Can you put the toys away,

Toys away, toys away?

Can you put the toys away?

It’s time to end our play.
content.title: Transitions

framework_items.full_statement: Follows Musical Instructions

Choreographic Understanding
Express Emotion Through Dance
Demonstrates Rhythm and Beat Understanding

resources.code: undefined.Correo electrnico para la familia (espaol)
resources.title: Correo electrnico para la familia (espaol)
resources.description:
Queridas familias,

Esta semana comenzamos un nuevo tema en nuestro salón de clases, “Marvelous Me”. En la primera semana de este tema, los niños conocerán su salón de clases, sus maestros, sus compañeros y el entorno escolar. Al final de la semana, su hijo comenzará a sentirse como en casa a medida que se sienta más cómodo siendo parte de la familia escolar. Su hijo también aprenderá sobre las fantásticas formas en que puede mover su cuerpo, identificar diferentes sentimientos e interactuar con otros para cooperar y completar tareas. ¡Todo lo que hacemos esta semana está relacionado con nuestros objetivos del Tema 1 para aprender sobre nuestros maravillosos cuerpos!

Ayude a su hijo a seguir aprendiendo en casa. Haga que su hijo se recueste sobre una hoja grande de papel o cartón y trace todo su cuerpo. Deje volar su creatividad mientras se colorean los ojos, la nariz y la boca. Señale cada parte del cuerpo, nómbrela y diga qué hace. Anime a su hijo a colorear la ropa que le gusta usar.

El libro de cuentos de esta semana, "My Super Body", se puede encontrar en https://lilypad2.frogstreet.com/public/resouce-detail/dbc02258-c418-4b77-87b7-400ec0e62459

¡Estamos muy emocionados de seguir explorando con tu pequeño!

 

Atentamente,

related_by_items.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Clo Cir.Closing Circle - Day 1
related_by_items.title: Closing Circle - Day 1

resources.code: undefined.Email to Family (English)
resources.title: Email to Family (English)
resources.description:
Dear Families,

This week we’re beginning a new theme in our classroom, “Marvelous Me”. In the first week of this theme, children will be introduced to their classroom, teacher, classmates, and the school environment. Your child will also learn about the fantastic ways they can move their body, identify different feelings, and interact with others to cooperate and complete tasks. Everything we do this week is related to our Theme 1 objectives to learn about our marvelous bodies!

Help your child to keep learning at home. Have your child lie down on a large piece of paper or cardboard and trace around their entire body. Let their creativity run wild as they color in their eyes, nose, and mouth. Point to each body part, name it, and tell what it does. Encourage your child to color the clothes they like to wear.

This week’s storybook, “My Super Body” can be found at: https://lilypad2.frogstreet.com/public/resouce-detail/dbc02258-c418-4b77-87b7-400ec0e62459

We’re so excited to continue exploring with your little one!

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Greet Cir.Fernando Unite: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes
resources.title: Fernando Unite: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes

related_by_items.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Greet Cir.Greeting Circle
related_by_items.title: Greeting Circle
related_by_items.short_description: Conscious Discipline Practices and Morning Message

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Greet Cir.Greeting Circle
resources.title: Greeting Circle
resources.short_description: Conscious Discipline Practices and Morning Message

content.text:
UNITE

Display Fernando’s Playhouse, with Fernando inside. Invite a volunteer to “wake” Fernando.

Display the Fernando Unite Video and sing Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes. Encourage children to dance along. After, invite volunteers to point to their ears, eyes, mouth, and nose.

Tell children they will be learning about their marvelous body and how it moves. Display the marvelous Vocabulary Card. Define marvelous as wonderful and the very best quality. For example, you might see a marvelous butterfly or attend a marvelous party. And, our bodies are marvelous, too!  

 

Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes Lyrics

Head, shoulders, knees and toes,

Knees and toes.

Head, shoulders, knees and toes,

Knees and toes.

Eyes and ears and mouth and nose.

Head, shoulders, knees and toes,

Knees and toes.

(Repeat)

 

CALM

S.T.A.R. (Smile, Take a deep breath And Relax) is a calming strategy. Explain deep breathing can help us feel relaxed.

Have children pretend to smell a flower (inhale through nose) and blow out a candle (exhale through mouth). Display the Calming Strategies Poster and refer to the S.T.A.R. icon.

 

CONNECT

Refer to the Greetings Poster and explain greeting others in a friendly way helps us get to know each other. Introduce Fernando as a member of the class and shake his hand.

Invite children to greet Fernando by waving. Once children greet Fernando, invite them to greet the child sitting next to them.

Encourage them to make eye contact and be gentle. Offer choices such as high-five, hug, fist bump, and wave.

 

COMMIT

The first classroom commitment starts with you!

Introduce your job as the Safekeeper. Say, My job is to keep you safe. And it’s your job to help keep the classroom safe. Explain one way to keep the classroom safe is to use “walking feet”. Discuss and demonstrate “walking feet”. Demonstrate “running feet” and how it is not safe and can cause accidents.

Refer to the “walking feet” icon on the Commitments Poster. Encourage children to commit to using “walking feet”.

The Morning Message is a short, 5-minute activity conducted each morning, specifically crafted to introduce and reinforce fundamental literacy skills, including:

  • Phonological Awareness
  • Print Concepts
  • Alphabet Knowledge

You will find detailed instructions for the Morning Message in your weekly guide starting in Theme 1, Week 3. In Theme 1 Weeks 1 and 2, you may take the 5 minutes you would normally allocate for the Morning Message to introduce and familiarize yourself with the Greeting Circle, and build classroom routines that support the Unite, Calm, Connect, and Commit goals.
content.title: Morning Message

inclusive_strategies.text:
Children with sensory processing issues often do not like to be touched. Encourage them to wave instead.

Holding hands and walking with a peer will help children with developmental delays practice using “walking feet”.

cultural_responsiveness.text: Be sure to note that bodies come in all shapes and sizes, and all bodies are good bodies. Bodies look different from one another and they’re all marvelous.

content.text:
POSTERS

  • Calming Strategies
  • Greetings
  • Commitments

VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

OTHER MATERIALS

  • Fernando with house

framework_items.full_statement: Demonstrates Empathy
Demonstrates Cooperative Play
Recognizing Family and Community Roles

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Math Center
resources.title: Math Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Math

content.text: Gather collections of recyclables or other common objects children can sort (coins, rocks, bottle caps, buttons, pom-poms). Each collection should have items within it that vary in size, color, or shape. Prepare a label for each collection by printing the name of the material next to a picture of it. Attach the label to the plastic tub in which the material is stored.
content.title: Prepare

content.text:
Sorting Collections

Encourage children to use bowls to sort items from each collection. Explain sorting is putting things together that have the same attributes. Demonstrate how to use tweezers or spoons to move items from the tubs to the sorting bowls.

 

Reflect: What attribute did you sort by?

Exploring Collections

Introduce different types of collections children can explore. Store each collection inside a tub labeled with a matching picture and printed word. Model how to observe and inspect the materials closely.

Reflect: What did you observe? How are they alike/ different?
content.title: Math Center

inclusive_strategies.text: Math Center: Instead of bowls, children with delays and motor challenges will find it easier to sort into muffin pans. You may also provide items on a tray for them to sort/move on a smooth surface from one space to the other.

content.text:
• sorting collections
  • collection labels
  • tubs
  • bowls for sorting
  • spoons or tweezers

tips_strategies.text:
SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

Math Center: Model how to use kind words such as “please” and “thank you” while sharing collection materials.

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

framework_items.full_statement: Child can group objects or pictures based on shared characteristics.
Child can explain why they have grouped items in a particular way.
Comparison and Differentiation
Child can distinguish between different categories (i.e., color, size, shape).

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Literacy Center
resources.title: Literacy Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Literacy

tips_strategies.text:
SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

content.text:
• tactile name cards
  • paper
  • crayons
  • name puzzles
  • plastic letters

columns.text: Use white glue to write each child’s name on a 5" x 7" index card. Allow the glue letters to dry. You may need to trace over the name with glue a second time so the letters are raised from the card.
columns.title: Tactile Name Cards

columns.text: Print each child’s name on a 9" x 10" sheet of cardstock. Leave a space between each letter. Make puzzle cuts between the letters. Place each child’s puzzle pieces in a storage bag.
columns.title: Name Puzzles

content.text:
Tactile Name Cards 

Invite children to place paper over their name card and rub with crayon. Children will see the letters appear on the paper. Have children close their eyes and trace over the first letter of their name. Reflect: What did the letters feel like?

Name Puzzles

Invite children to put together their name puzzle. When children complete their puzzle, have them use plastic letters to copy their name. Reflect: Where else do you see your name in the room?
content.title: Activity

framework_items.full_statement: Child exhibits coordinated movements in relation to spatial awareness, including maneuvering around obstacles.
Child displays growing strength in small muscle groups
Child exhibits steady improvement in fine-motor tasks

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Gross Motor Center
resources.title: Gross Motor Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Gross Motor skills

content.text:
• masking tape
  • beanbag
  • rope or yarn
Use rope or yarn to create a wavy line. Have children walk holding their arms out to their side. Reflect: Was it more difficult to walk the wavy line or the zigzag line? Why?

tips_strategies.text:
SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

content.text: Use masking tape to make a zigzag on the floor. Invite children to walk forward and backward a few times. Then, have them repeat with a beanbag on their head. Remind children their feet and legs allow them to enjoy this activity. Reflect: How were you able to walk backwards?
content.title: Activity

framework_items.full_statement: Shares toys and materials with other children during play.
Child exhibits coordinated movements in relation to spatial awareness, including maneuvering around obstacles.
Engages in group activities or games, cooperating with peers to achieve common goals.

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Creativity Center
resources.title: Creativity Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Creativity

columns.text: Mix flavored gelatin using half the amount of water as the directions state on the box. Have children use the mixture for paint. When it dries, children can scratch- and-sniff their artwork.
columns.title: Scratch-and-Sniff Paint

SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

inclusive_strategies.text: Creativity Center: Let children with tactile sensitivity use gloves or a sponge to finger paint.

content.text:
• finger paint
  • paper
  • scratch-and-sniff paint
Add scratch-and-sniff paint. While children paint, ask them to sniff and name the scent. When the picture is dry, have them scratch- and-sniff again. Reflect: How were you able to smell the scent?

Invite children to finger paint directly on the tabletop. Then, press their painted hands onto a sheet of paper to create handprints. Discuss the names of the fingers (thumb, index, middle, ring, pinkie). Reflect: Which finger did you use most?
content.title: Activity

framework_items.full_statement: Child exhibits steady improvement in fine-motor tasks
Child demonstrates accurate handling and manipulation of objects
Child shows significant improvements in muscle strength and can effectively handle objects like balls, hoops, or bicycles.

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Sensory Center
resources.title: Sensory Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Sensory

content.text: Invite children to match the scent canisters that smell the same. Change the scents throughout the week. Remind children their nose helps them enjoy this activity. Reflect: Which scents did you smell? Which one was your favorite?
content.title: Activity

content.text: Switch out the scented canisters with scented dough. Reflect: Did the scents smell the same in the canisters as they did in the dough?

tips_strategies.text:
SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

Sensory Center: Model how to share the scent canisters by using words such as:

  • May I please have....
  • I’m smelling the canister now. Please wait your turn.
  • Would you like to sniff with me?

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

content.text:
• scent canisters
  • scented dough

multilingual_learners.text: Sensory Center: Invite children to indicate with a “thumbs up” or a “thumbs down” if they like the smell of each scent canister.

columns.text: Soak cotton balls in essential oil or food flavoring extracts. Place the cotton balls in small tubs with holes poked in the lid. Make 2 tubs for each scent. Chamomile, lavender, and orange are calming scents. Peppermint, lemon, and cinnamon increase mental alertness.
columns.title: Scent Canisters

framework_items.full_statement: The child starts to analyze and reason out the differences and similarities of objects and phenomena through keen observation. They begin to understand the basic concept of comparing, enabling them to make more sophisticated analyses in the future.
Child demonstrates accurate handling and manipulation of objects

The child is able to differentiate between various objects and phenomena based on their observable characteristics such as size, color, shape, and texture. This skill builds the foundation for making comparisons and distinctions between different phenomena.

resources.code: Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Centers.Writer's Center
resources.title: Writer's Center
resources.short_description: Inquiry and Exploration center set up for Writing skills

inclusive_strategies.text: Writer’s Center: Provide children with various sized writing utensils to help with fine motor and graphomotor skills.

content.text: Encourage children to draw pictures of things they like to hear or smell. With children’s permission, label their drawings. Reflect: What would you like to share about your drawing?

tips_strategies.text:
SETTING BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS

Setting behavioral expectations for center time is crucial for year-long harmony and successful learning. 

Start the year by setting expectations of how children should work together and speak to each other while in centers.

Start by role-playing different scenarios for children to understand expected behaviors.

 

CHOICE OVERLOAD

Children can become overwhelmed with too many choices during Inquiry and Exploration. At the beginning of the year, choose two centers the children would enjoy and introduce those first, then slowly introduce the other centers once ready.

Less is more when decorating your classroom. Children are easily overstimulated. Reduce clutter in the classroom and only display items that have an instructional purpose for the day. When displaying information to children, ensure it is at their eye level.

content.text:
• paper
  • crayons

Invite children to draw a self-portrait, adding as many body parts as possible. With children’s permission, label the body parts on their paper. Remind children it is their hands that allow them to create beautiful drawings. Reflect: Can you name the body parts in your picture?
content.title: Activity

framework_items.full_statement: 'Child uses imaginative thinking to create new ideas or interpretations.'
'Child conveys ideas and emotions through various forms of art, drama, and play.'
Child demonstrates accurate handling and manipulation of objects
Child exhibits steady improvement in fine-motor tasks

resources.code: DRAFT - Preschool 2024 (native).Theme 1: Marvelous Me.wk2.Clo Cir.Closing Circle - Day 1
resources.title: Closing Circle - Day 1
resources.short_description: Reflect on Daily Commitments made during Greeting Circle

content.text:
VOCABULARY CARDS

  • marvelous

OTHER MATERIALS

  • Fernando with House

columns.text: Display the marvelous Vocabulary Card. Review the definition as the very best quality. Ask, What do you think is marvelous?
columns.title: Reflect

columns.text: On Day 1, send home the “Physical Me” family letter.
columns.title: Family Connections

content.text:
Reflect on Daily Commitments made during Greeting Circle. Ask children if they have used “walking feet”. Give some specific examples you observed of children using “walking feet”. If children were successful, have them say, I did it! If children were not successful, encourage them to say, Oops! I will practice more tomorrow.

Display Fernando’s Playhouse and ask a volunteer to put him to sleep inside for the night.
content.title: Daily
